paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b retain any atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation, as evidenced by JWST MIRI phase-curve spectroscopy measuring thermal phase variation and spectral structure around the 15 um CO2 band?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed system
datasets_or_cohorts.description: TRAPPIST-1 b phase-resolved thermal spectra obtained via JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Null scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: No-atmosphere model with minimal heat redistribution, serving as the baseline comparison for atmosphere detection.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere model with significant greenhouse gas absorption, testing for CO2 spectral features around 15 um.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Oxidized composition model with weaker CO2 signature constraints, representing an alternative atmospheric composition.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions including circulation patterns, opacity priors, and cloud treatment affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
Degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation assumptions remain significant.
